R. China. b Industrial Crop Research Institute, Yunnan Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Kunming 650205, Yunnan, PR China Industrial Crop Research Institute, Yunnan Academy of Agricultural Sciences Kunming Yunnan 650205 PR China Industrial Crop Research Institute, Yunnan Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Kunming, 650205, Yunnan, P. R. China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this paper. As an excellent bioorthogonal reaction, CuAAC reaction has been widely used in biological research. In this work, three cyclodextrin derivatives β-CD-3, β-CD-4 and CD-P were synthesized in different ways. Among them, use of trace amounts of the β-CD-3 could efficiently promote the CuAAC reaction under mild conditions. Only using 20 ppm concentration of β-CD-3-Cu(I), the TON of the reaction was up to 45,000, and the catalyst still has high catalytic activity after repeated cycling, which may be attributed to its chelating structure formed by coordination with copper more stable than β-CD-4-Cu(I) and CD-P-Cu(I). In addition, we have also proved that the construction of supramolecular catalytic systems can effectively achieve extracellular click reactions at ultra-low concentrations, and therefore can be applied to the synthesis of various functional compounds such as catalysis, imaging, targeting and medicine. Graphical Abstract This novel supramolecular (β-CD-3) catalytic system could accelerate the CuAAC reaction and provide a green or extracellular path for efficient synthesis of organic molecules. ga1 Keywords Bioorthogonal chemistry Click reaction CuAAC Supramolecular catalysis Polycyclodextrin Triazole Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The concept of “click chemistry” was first proposed by Sharpless in 2001 [1]. Once proposed, it has received wide attention and become one of the hot spots in the fields of biology, chemistry, materials and medicine at home and abroad. The most distinctive characteristics of click chemistry are simple reaction conditions, high yield, no by-products, good tolerance of functional group, and strong stereoselectivity. Among them, the reaction of Cu(I)-catalyzed azide alkyne to 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole cycloaddition (CuAAC), as a representative reaction of click chemistry, has been widely used in pharmaceutical development, functional materials and organic synthesis. For the active Cu species used in this CuAAC reaction, CuSO4 is generally reduced with sodium ascorbate (NaAsc), which is called Sharpless-Fokin catalyst [2]. CuAAC reaction is an excellent bioorthogonal reaction [3] with incredible efficiency, chemical selectivity and compatibility with functional groups which can link very complex molecules and is widely used in the biological field (anticancer agents [4–6], antibacterial agents [7–9], antiviral agents [10,11], biomedical imaging [12–15], etc.). However, the large dose of copper in the catalytic process leads to high copper residue in practical application, which limits its application in biological transfer and in vivo synthesis. Some ligands have been proved to significantly accelerate the reaction and reduce the amount of copper, with nitrogen/nitrous compounds being the main ones. It has been shown that azolyl ring compounds have excellently strong coordination capability to anchor metal, especially TBTA and its analogs ( Scheme 1). TBTA was first developed as a ligand in 2004 by Fokin group [16], which has a triazole ring structure and can form strong coordination bonds with copper. Under mild reaction conditions, 1 mol % Cu can effectively catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of alkynes and azides. However, the use of TBTA with poor water solubility requires organic solvents, which limits its application in biological environment. Subsequently, in 2010, Finn group [17] replaced the benzene ring in TBTA with hydroxypropyl group to increase the water solubility of TBTA, resulting in the synthesis of THPTA, which not only catalyzes the addition reaction of alkynes and azides in water, but also has been shown to have a protective effect on cells and can be used for cell surface labeling. In addition, Wu Group [18] synthesized BTTES in 2010 by substituting the three phenyl rings of TBTA with two tert-butyl groups and one sulfonate, respectively, resulting in a balance of reactivity and solubility. The catalyst can not only catalyze the addition reaction of alkyne and azide effectively, but also be used to image polysaccharide biosynthesis at the early stage of zebrafish embryo development. However, in practice, about 10 % of the embryo development will be impaired. In order to improve the labeling efficiency and biocompatibility of CuAAC, in 2011, the sulfonate group of BTTES was replaced by the acetate group to generate a new ligand BTTAA [19]. The acetic acid ester functional group not only has negative charge, but also can be used as an additional ligand to coordinate with Cu which can increase the electron density of the metal center and promote the formation of ring intermediates to achieve additional acceleration, and is proved to have good biocompatibility. The above are the applications of TBTA and its analogs as small molecular ligands in the catalytic azide cycloaddition of alkynes. In 2016, Astruct group first used triazole group to modify PEG to obtain amphiphilic tris-trz-PEG ligand [20]. Only parts per million amount of Cu(I) were necessary to reach quantitative yields of triazole products with TONs up to 86,000 and TOFs of 3600 h−1. The yield of 93 % was also successfully achieved in large-scale synthesis. The Zimmerman group [21] synthesized single-chain nanoparticles (SCNP-1) modified TBTA units to coordinate with copper as an artificial metal enzyme, which can efficiently catalyze the CuAAC reaction on protein surface and cell surface glycans. Subsequently, they [22] synthesized SCNP-2 by gating technology to achieve in situ synthesis and screening of anticancer drugs without interfering with intracellular functions. These polymers containing TBTA-like units provided metal centers and cavities as ligands to successfully promote CuAAC in cell with lowest amount of cooper. β-Cyclodextrin (β-CD) is a non-toxic cyclic oligosaccharide containing 7 glucose units with an external hydrophilic and internal hydrophobic cavity structure, which can catalyze small molecular reactions in water under relatively mild conditions [23–27]. Lee's group used β-CD as a phase transfer catalyst for the first time to catalyze the CuAAC reaction in water at room temperature, achieving 93.3 % conversion within 10 min [28], then β-CD was used to synthesize glycidyl triazole polymer in water [29].Larin and Shankar et al. used β-CD to catalyze the synthesis of functionalized bissubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles from multicomponent substrates [30,31]. Yang group used bis-cyclodextrin and bis-adamantane to form linear supramolecular compounds, which could efficiently accelerate the CuAAC reaction [32]. However, the amount of catalyst used is relatively high, and its application is limited to in vitro catalytic reactions. Interestingly, we found that triple-β-cyclodextrin (β-CD-3) [33–35] have both TBTA-like structure and cyclodextrin endowed with solubilization and molecular recognition. In addition, we synthesized water-soluble β-CD-4 and water-insoluble CD-P based on β-CD-3, both of which contain abundant triazole rings and cyclodextrin units. Based on the strong coordination ability of tridentate azoles and the molecular container effect of cyclodextrin, they are potentially expected to construct a supermolecular catalytic system in water and in cell. 2 Result and discussion For the construction of supramolecular catalytic system, the supramolecular catalysts β-CD-3-Cu(I), β-CD-4-Cu(I), and CD-P-Cu(I) were synthesized. The detailed preparation for β-CD-3 ligand is shown in Scheme 2 and Supporting Information as reported previously [35] with some changes, which was analyzed via 1H NMR, MALDI-TOF-MS, and DLS (Dynamic Light Scattering) test (Fig. S7, S8 and S9). The detailed preparation for β-CD-4, β-CD-4-Cu(I), CD-P, and CD-P-Cu(I) were shown in Supporting Information. The novel click catalyst was prepared by adding CuSO4·5H2O to an aqueous solution containing the water soluble β-CD-3 ligand under nitrogen to form a precatalyst β-CD-3-Cu(II), followed by adding sodium ascorbate to reduce the catalyst in situ to a catalyst β-CD-3-Cu(I) (Scheme 2 and Supporting Information). The synthetic procedure from β-CD-3 to β-CD-3-Cu(I) has been monitored by UV−vis ( Fig. 1), X-ray diffraction ( Fig. 2), 1H NMR spectroscopy ( Fig. 3), TEM analysis ( Fig. 4) and XPS ( Fig. 5). In the UV–visible spectrum, the absorption peak of copper sulfate is in the range of 700–800 nm (Fig. 1, insert), which is attributed to the d-d transition of Cu (II). When Cu (II) is coordinated with the triazole ring, the absorption peak disappears. Upon further reduction by NaAsc (3 equiv/mol of CuSO4), the β-CD-3-Cu(I) complex exhibits a moderate intensity peak in the range of 250–400 nm (main absorption at 290 nm, Fig. 1) which is assigned to a metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transition. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of β-CD, β-CD-3 and β-CD-3-Cu(I) are presented in Fig. 2. β-CD generated a large number of sharp and strong peaks which indicated that it was natural crystalline. The comparison shows that β-CD-3 (red curve) is amorphous and exhibits strong and broad characteristic diffraction peaks at 15–30°. XRD results show that the ligand has been synthesized. In addition, the new XRD peaks (blue curve) of β-CD-3-Cu(I) at 31° and 41° correspond to 100 and 200 crystal planes of Cu, respectively, indicating that Cu exists in β-CD-3-Cu(I). The synthesis of the catalyst was confirmed by 1H NMR using D2O as solvent (Fig. 3). After the addition of Cu2+, the proton nuclear magnetic resonance signal on the triazole ring of β-CD-3 disappeared due to the paramagnetic effect of Cu(II), indicating that it was complexed [36]. When NaAsc was added, the proton nuclear magnetic resonance signal on the triazole appeared again, but the signal shifted to 8.021 ppm compared with the previous 7.931 ppm signal, indicating that the triazole ring was successfully coordinated with Cu(I) [36,37]. Fig. 4 is the TEM images and the HR-TEM images of β-CD-3-Cu(I). By comparing Fig. 4A and Fig. 4B, it is found that the latter has obvious black spots. We speculate that the black spots are copper ions. Subsequently, in order to confirm our conjecture, we obtained the HR-TEM image of β-CD-3-Cu(I) (Fig. 4C). From Fig. 4C, it is obvious that the average interplanar distance is 0.29 nm, which corresponds to copper and confirms our conjecture. Moreover, we analyzed the valence state of copper in the catalyst by XPS (Fig. 5). Cu2p indicates that β-CD-3-Cu(I) does not contain Cu(II). After fitting calculation by CuLMM, we determined that copper exists in the form of Cu(I) (Fig. 5, insert). At the same time, we performed DLS test (Fig. S9) and found that the average particle size of β-CD-3 was 1356 nm, which may be due to the aggregation of cyclodextrin. In addition, we also determined by ICP-MS that the Cu content of β-CD-3 was 0.39 %, while the metal content of β-CD-3 was 2.14 %, minus the copper content of β-CD-3 itself was 1.75 % (Supporting Information, Equation S1), indicating that the coordination ratio of copper to β-CD-3 was 1: 1. Next, we studied the catalytic efficiency of β-CD-3-Cu(I), β-CD-4-Cu(I), and CD-P-Cu(I) in CuAAC reaction. To this end, the catalysts ( Scheme 3) of Cu(I) (A), β-CD + Cu(I) (B), TBTA + Cu(I) (C), β-CD-3-Cu(I) (D), β-CD-4-Cu(I) (E) and CD-P-Cu(I) (F) were compared with each other for the CuAAC of benzyl azide and phenylacetylene in water under identical conditions. The result is shown in Fig. 6. β-CD can be used as a supramolecular catalyst to catalyze organic chemical reactions in water. Previous studies [28] have shown that 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazoles can be click-synthesized in high yields under mild conditions due to the effective activation of β-CD. However, in this study, by adding β-CD, compared with the pure monovalent copper catalyst (A), no significant change in catalytic activity was found at the addition amount of the catalyst of 50 ppm. But at 2000 ppm, the catalytic effect is improved. It appears that the concentration of β-CD played a key role in the previous studies [28]. Therefore, only cyclodextrin cannot achieve a satisfactory yield because the copper is the crucial factor in the reaction. We are also interested in whether the addition of an azole ring contributes to the catalytic system. To this end, we designed and synthesized a catalytic system composed of TBTA and monovalent copper (C). The results showed that different catalysts B and C obtained similar yields, indicating the acceleration of nitrogen-based ligands in the reaction, thereby increasing the yield. Excitingly, the products were obtained in high isolated yields in 2000, 200, 100 and 50 ppm when β-CD-3-Cu(I) was used to catalyze the reaction. In addition, we synthesized β-CD-4 (E) and Cyclodextrin-Polymer (CD-P) (F), both of which are rich in triazole, and unexpectedly, the catalytic effect is not ideal, which may be that β-CD-4 and CD-P do not form a chelating structure when coordinating with Cu. This also indirectly shows that the effect of the monotriazlole ring product we synthesized on the autocatalysis or reaction inhibition of the system is negligible due to hardly forming stable coordinating with copper [38]. In summary, as shown in Fig. 6, trace amounts of β-CD-3 can efficiently catalyze the reaction due to (i) the chelation effect, (ii) ligand β-CD-3 contains three triazoles that increase the electron density of the metal center, (iii) a β-CD-3 ligand containing three cavities allowing homogeneous “click” reactions in water. The catalytic efficiency of β-CD-3-Cu(I) was tested using benzyl azide and phenylacetylene as template substrates ( Table 1). The reaction was carried out in the presence of 2000, 1000 and 100 ppm β-CD-3-Cu(I) at room temperature in water for 20 h, and the target compound was obtained in 95 % yield (Table 1, Entry 1–3). When the amount of catalyst decreased to 50 ppm, the conversion rate of the substrate was still 100 %, the yield decreased to 92 % (Table 1, Entry 4). While the conversion rate decreased to 90 % at 10 ppm, and the yield decreased to 80 % (Table 1, Entry 6). At this time, the TON reached a maximum of 80000, while the TOF value also reached a maximum of 4000. When the amount of catalyst is further reduced to 5 ppm (Table 1, Entry 7), the conversion and yield of the reaction decrease significantly. When 20 ppm is used, the conversion rate reaches 100 % while the yield is as high as 90 %, TON is 45,000, and TOF is 2250 (Table 1, Entry 5). Notably, there is no desired product obtained without catalyst (Table 1, entry 8). Taken together, we believe that 20 ppm is the best dose. Under the reaction conditions, we also carried out the expansion reaction and obtained the target product in 90 % isolated yield (Table 1, Entry 5). In addition, the recovery of the catalyst is also quite successful, and the catalyst can be retained in the extracted aqueous phase for the next reaction (Table 1, Entry 5). Based on previous explorations, we used benzyl azide and various alkynes to evaluate the performance of the catalyst. It was found that the catalyst had good tolerance to various functional groups and could obtain the target compound in excellent yield ( Table 2). It can be seen from the reaction results that the substrate yields of ortho-, meta-, and para-electron donor substituents were slightly higher than those of electron-withdrawing substituents (Table 2, Entries 2–13). Since the heteroatoms were electron-withdrawing substituents, the corresponding yields of heterocyclic alkyne substrates were also lower than those of phenylacetylene (Table 2, Entries 14–15). Surprisingly, 1-Heptyne, ethynyl ferrocene and trimethylsilyl acetylene substrates also has an excellent catalytic effect (Table 2, Entries 16–18), in order to explore its potential application in biology, we used the fluorescent dye 3-azido-7-hydroxy-coumarin[39] as the reaction substrate, and the product was also obtained in excellent yield (Table 2, Entries 19). In addition, for most of these reaction products, it is not necessary to purify them by silica gel chromatography. After the reaction, the system only contains water-insoluble products, which can be obtained by simple extraction-filtration, reflecting the advantages of β-CD-3 in water catalysis. From the perspective of industrial chemistry, catalyst recycling rate is one of the important parameters to measure the catalyst. In this study, the reusability of the β-CD-3-Cu(I) catalyst was evaluated in CuAAC reaction and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The model reactions and optimized conditions were selected for the reusability study. After completion of each cycle, the separated catalyst could be used in the next run without changing the reaction conditions. In the first cycle, the yield was 90 % and the catalytic system still behaved high catalytic activity with a yield of 75 % after five cycles. We speculated that the reduction of catalytic efficiency may be due to the loss of some water phase in the extraction process, resulting in the reduction of catalyst amount. Next, a one-pot process involving the formation of the organic azide in situ from the corresponding bromide with sodium azide was carried out as shown in Table 3. Under the above-mentioned reaction conditions, benzyl bromide was converted into the triazole in 90 % yield. This shows that during the reaction, benzyl bromide is almost equivalently converted to the corresponding organic azide, which effectively avoids the process of preparing organic azides in advance. It is well known that organic azides are not easy to preserve. To further explore the supramolecular catalytic efficiency and potential biological applications of β-CD-3, we used fluorescence detection reactions between the azide 1 and alkyne 2 at the concentration of 20 μM ( Fig. 8A). We used separately 0.6 μM β-CD-3, 1 μM β-CD-3 and 1 μM β-CD for the experiment. The intensity was monitored by fluorimetry every 1 min at λem = 478 nm with λex = 405 nm. The reaction conversion was calculated from the observed fluorescence intensity using pure product (3 s) as the standard. Relative rates were determined as follows. We observed that the fluorescence intensity of the reaction with 1 μM β-CD-3 increased sharply in the first ten minutes and then stabilized (Fig. 8B). The fluorescence intensity reached the maximum at 13 min, and the maximum conversion rate was 96.6 %, indicating that the substrate reaction was over (Fig. 8 C). While with 0.6 μM β-CD-3, the conversion rate increased slowly after 10 min and reached 81.9 % at 25 min and when we used 1 μM β-CD, the reaction conversion reached the maximum value in the 5 min and then no longer changed (Fig. 8C). This shows that the CuAAc reaction can be completed rapidly at lower concentration assisted with β-CD-3. To test whether the extracellular catalyst is active and has the ability to produce small molecule products that can subsequently enter the cell through passive diffusion ( Fig. 9). In PBS solution, HeLa cells and β-CD-3 were used for the click reaction between 1 (3-azido-7-hydroxycoumarin) and 2 (1-ethynyl-4-methoxybenzene), and three groups of a, b and c were set as control groups. Group a was the blank group, group b was catalyzed by 1 μM Cu(I), and group c was catalyzed by 1 μM of β-CD-3 and Cu(I). When no catalyst was added, no fluorescence was observed in the cells, indicating that no reaction occurred without catalyst. Weak fluorescence can be observed when using Cu(I), indicating that Cu(I) has a certain catalytic effect but not ideal. When we use β-CD-3-Cu(I) as catalyst, strong fluorescence can be observed, which not only shows the excellent catalytic performance of β-CD-3-Cu(I), consistent with the previous experimental results, but also shows that the reaction products are easy to diffuse in cells. This primary experiment implies that supramolecular catalytic system could be constructed in cell for imaging, it is proved that supramolecular has great potential in the field of in vivo catalysis and imaging. 3 Conclusions In summary, we synthesized three different cyclodextrin derivatives (β-CD-3, β-CD-4 and CD-P), which all contain triazole ring structure. After screening, β-CD-3 has excellent catalytic performance. We used low-concentration β-CD-3 to efficiently catalyze CuAAC reaction under green conditions. The excellent catalytic performance of β-CD-3 was derived from the synergistic effect of the strong coordination ability of triazole and the function of cyclodextrin molecular container. This study expanded the scope of Sharpless-Fokin catalyst. We demonstrated that water-soluble β-CD-3 could be easily removed after the reaction, and could be applied to extracellular catalysis. A small amount of catalyst can not only significantly reduce the cost of industrial catalysis, but also is expected to be used in vivo imaging and in situ synthesis of potential drug molecules. coredata.dc:description: As an excellent bioorthogonal reaction, CuAAC reaction has been widely used in biological research. In this work, three cyclodextrin derivatives β-CD-3, β-CD-4 and CD-P were synthesized in different ways. Among them, use of trace amounts of the β-CD-3 could efficiently promote the CuAAC reaction under mild conditions. Only using 20 ppm concentration of β-CD-3-Cu(I), the TON of the reaction was up to 45,000, and the catalyst still has high catalytic activity after repeated cycling, which may be attributed to its chelating structure formed by coordination with copper more stable than β-CD-4-Cu(I) and CD-P-Cu(I). In addition, we have also proved that the construction of supramolecular catalytic systems can effectively achieve extracellular click reactions at ultra-low concentrations, and therefore can be applied to the synthesis of various functional compounds such as catalysis, imaging, targeting and medicine.
coredata.dc:title: Cyclodextrin-based multifunctional supramolecular catalysts for aqueous CuAAC reaction
